moves.1... e5: I gave him an easy pawn.  A truly dumb mistake on my part.  While it opens up the board, it's not what I wanted to do.
moves.2... d6: Down a pawn, my tack is going to be conservative.  Might as well pressure his knight and open up the board.  I could have pressured with the queen, but didn't want to block up the avenues for developing other pieces.  I certainly didn't want to offer a trade by moving Nc6.
moves.3. Nf3:
According to the book ...
1. Nf3 e5 2. Nxe5 d6 3. Nf3
A04: Reti opening
moves.3... Bg4: A bit aggressive all things considered, but it does present some options down the road.
moves.4. c4: Dad's been playing the c-pawn early a lot lately.  I seem to see this a lot lately, and I've started doing so myself as white.
moves.4... Nd7: I'm not sure why I'm not developing my king side at this point.  I suppose I'm trying to build support for an eventual pawn move to c5.
moves.5. d4: Dad has a strong center pawn structure now.
moves.5... Qf6: This seems like a mistake as it blocks the kingside development even further.
moves.6... Bxf3: This move was not necessary.  It only speeds up the game.  With a pawn down, this probably wasn't wise.  The only advantage it confers is a stacked pawn structure.
moves.7. exf3: I'm not sure I would have exposed the King here, but he did.
moves.8. Be3: A simple block that also develops the queenside.
moves.8... Ne7: I'm looking ahead to the possibility of Nf5 thus pressuring the bishop blocking the queen check.
moves.9. Nb5: Massive knight fork possibility at Nxc7 .
moves.9... Kd8: Argh, pesky knights.  Obviously, a6 leads to a fork.  O-O-O loses a pawn.  Rc8 loses a pawn.  I think Kd8 is the only move that I have here. Thoughts?  By moving the king, I've given up the ability to castle either way.
moves.10. Qb3: With the king out of position, it makes sense to pressure that side of the board.
moves.11. Nxd6: An interesting sacrifice.  I later commented to Dad that this wasn't necessary, but Dad says he saw a possible forced draw.  With a pawn advantage, I think he's being quite charitable.  In any event, this leads to an even situation.
moves.11... Qxd6: At this point, my center is destroyed, my king is out of position, and my development is a bit behind that of white.
moves.12. Qxb7: Back to even.  Wouldn't Nb6 have been better?
moves.12... Qb8: But, I choose a more aggressive defense and offer the queen trade.
moves.13. Qxb8+: Dad accepts the queen trade.  At this point, a draw seems likely.
moves.13... Rxb8: With the queen trade, I gain control of the b file.
moves.14. b3: I might have preferred Ra-b1, but this works, too.
moves.14... Nf5: Looking for a knight-bishop trade at this stage in the game.
moves.15. Bd3: Final developing move for white.  All mid-level pieces are out, and white still has the option to castle.
moves.15... Bb4+:
I check here to at least temporarily delay white's castle.  I expected the following:
16.	Ke2 	Bc3
17.	Ra-c1 	Nxd4 
18.	Kd1 	Bb2
19.	Rb1 	Bc3
moves.16. Kd1: This seems to beg for Nxe3  fxe3.
moves.16... Bc3:
I expected this combination:
17.	Rc1 	Nxe3 
18.	fxe3 	Bb4
... and white followed suit.
moves.19. Rc2: With black having a black square bishop, this move is smart as it effectively diminishes the strength of that piece.
moves.19... g6: Countering the bishop's line to permit Rh8 to move.
moves.20. c5: This gets scary for black as the bishop may get trapped.
moves.20... Ba5: But, I think I'm overly worried here.  The bishop is not yet at risk for trap.  In any event, I back off.
moves.21. Ke2: White is slowly advancing his pieces making the board smaller for black.
moves.22... Kc7: I'm also trying to shorten the board for white, but I have less pawns to provide cover.
moves.23. Rb1: Although both of my rooks are controlling the open files, this is still smart as sets up the possibility of advancing the b pawn.
moves.23... Kd8: I see problems down the road for this side of the board, and I think my logic was to get the King over in support of the f, g and h pawns.
moves.24... Bc7: Time to get out of Dodge and start working on a f, g, h pawn attack.
moves.25... h5: Space is becoming important on the board, and I want to prevent g4.
moves.26. Be4: Nice pressure on the unprotected c pawn.
moves.27. Rd2: This shift creates the possibility of a d pawn attack and aligns the rook with the black king.
moves.28. d5: I probably didn't see this coming.  Nice move by white.
moves.28... cxd5:
I expected the following:
29.	Bxd5 	Re7
30.	c6 	Nf8
31.	Bc4  	Ke8
moves.29... Re7: I'm trying to retain control of the e file without giving up too much space.
moves.30. Bc6: Excellent move.  I probably didn't see this coming either.  The knight is trapped by the rook.  This was all set up in move 27.  I'm not at risk of losing a piece yet, but pressure is definitely mounting.
moves.30... a5: This move is an attempt to set up a counter-attack, i.e. a4.  At this point, white cannot capture bxa4 without losing a rook.
moves.32. axb4: Trade accepted.  White's better off for the trade as the pawn is still supported by a rook.
moves.32... Ke8: Still trying to get the king to support the f, g and h pawns.
moves.33. Ra2: This sets up potential pressure on the 7th rank but permits the king to escape.
moves.34. Bxd7: Accelerating the game further.  I generally don't mind trading a knight for a bishop late in the game.
moves.34... Rxd7: Back to even with control of the d file.
moves.35. Ke2: Recognizing and counteracting the down-the-road Rd2 threat.
moves.35... Be5: Sets up a possible attack on the b pawn.
moves.37. Ra4: Power against power, the definition of a draw.
moves.37... Rb7b5: I'm hoping to stop the pawn advancement.  I've also created the possibility of Rxc5 bxc5 Rxb3 trade.
moves.38... Bc7: Sets up the possibility of Ba5 bxa5 Rxb3 or other variations on this theme.
moves.39... Rb8b6: Now, white must defend and risks losing a pawn.
moves.40. Rc3: White's only option to keep the advanced pawn.
moves.40... Ke7: Why didn't I take the b pawn?  We'll never know.  I guess I was eying the c pawn.
moves.41. Ra2: White relinquishes the b pawn completely.
moves.42. Rd2: White blocks the king in support and controls the d file.
moves.42... Rb4b2: A pawn up, I seek to press for a draw.
moves.43. Rcc2: Black doesn't force the trade, but still offers it.
moves.44. Rxc2: At this point, black is up by one pawn again.
moves.44... Kd6: Black looks to go up 2 pawns.
moves.45. Kf3: There's nothing to be done for the c pawn, so white consolidates his one pawn advantage.
moves.45... Rxc6: Up 2 and offering a rook trade.
moves.46... Kxc6: Black is up 2 but down a pawn.
moves.47. e4: There's not much to say from here on out.  The game has some win possibilities for white, but I was fairly set on just not losing and avoiding any horrible mistakes.  When white offers a piece ...
moves.48. Kxe4: 2 to black but quickly losing pawns.  Lots of draw options here.
moves.49. Ke5: If white can separate the king from the pawns, a win is possible.
moves.49... Kd7: Perhaps a little later than would normally be comfortable, I staring moving my king back over in support.
moves.50. h3: The king can't move anywhere useful, so a safe move.
moves.50... Ke7: My only shot is to separate his king from the pawns.
moves.51. f5: If I take at this point, I could lose as it would definitely separate the h pawn from its support.
moves.51... Kf7: So, I move the king closer.
moves.52... Kxg6: Back to  2, now in support of the h pawn.
moves.53... Bg5+: h4 might have been more interesting as it would have trapped white's last h pawn.
moves.54... h4: I needed to do this earlier.
moves.55... Bxh4: 2, but I've not separated the king from his last pawn.
moves.56. Kg4: White's best move, since it keeps the bishop at bay.
moves.56... Bg5: Bd8 might have been better.  In any event, I offer the draw here and white accepts.  Good game Pop!
